thread.title: Bel Air protesters march on Rep. Harris' office to voice concerns about Obamacare repeal
thread.title_full: Bel Air protesters march on Rep. Harris' office to voice concerns about Obamacare repeal

author: DAVID ANDERSON
title: Bel Air protesters march on Rep. Harris' office to voice concerns about Obamacare repeal
text:
Bel Air protesters march on Rep. Harris' office to voice concerns about Obamacare repeal Protest outside Rep. Andy Harris' Bel Air office 
About 30 people came out Monday afternoon for a protest march through Bel Air to express their concerns over healthcare & other issues ending at Congressman Andy Harris' office. 
About 30 people came out Monday afternoon for a protest march through Bel Air to express their concerns over healthcare & other issues ending at Congressman Andy Harris' office. David Anderson , or Obamacare.
She and about 30 other people brought their concerns about the future of the ACA to the Bel Air office of U.S. Rep. Andy Harris Monday afternoon. The Republican Harris, who represents the northern half of Harford County in Congress, has been a vocal critic of the ACA since it was first proposed and supports its repeal. 
"I want Andy Harris to hear my voice," Hautzinger said. 
Led by members of the group Together We Will-Harford County/Upper Chesapeake, approximately 30 people came out Monday afternoon to hold their signs and march to Congressman Andy Harris' Bel Air office to express their concerns about healthcare and a variety of other issues. (MATT BUTTON | AEGIS STAFF) 
With the current push to repeal the ACA coming from President Donald Trump and congressional Republicans , enrollees such as Hautzinger aren't sure how they will get health insurance in the future. 
"I want details, I want to know if Medicaid is going to be cut, am I going to lose my insurance, if so what is his plan for me or people like me?" Hautzinger said. 
Led by Together We Will-Harford County/Upper Chesapeake, the protesters gathered at the intersection of Courtland Street and Hickory Avenue in downtown Bel Air, walked along Courtland to Main Street, then down Main to Churchville Road then gathered in front of the East Churchville Road shopping center where Harris' district office is located. 
They carried signs and chanted slogans such as "this is what democracy looks like," where is Andy, missing in action," and "ACA, fix it don't nix it!" 
Joppa resident Mary Erikson was holding her 9-year-old daughter's hand as they knelt and prayed with fellow March for Life participants in from of the U.S. Supreme Court building in Washington, D.C. Friday, when she burst into tears thinking of the babies whose lives had ended – before they started... 
Joppa resident Mary Erikson was holding her 9-year-old daughter's hand as they knelt and prayed with fellow March for Life participants in from of the U.S. Supreme Court building in Washington, D.C. Friday, when she burst into tears thinking of the babies whose lives had ended – before they started... (DAVID ANDERSON) 
The march prompted surprised looks and some rude comments from passersby, but several drivers honked their horns and gave the crowd a thumbs up. 
Members of the group, which included people who participated in last month's Women's March on Washington, planned to give Harris a letter outlining their request for him to participate in community town hall meetings about the ACA. 
"We have asked, we have called, written and Tweeted [Harris] to request a town hall with no response," Delane Lewis, founded of the Harford County Together We Will group, told the group when it stopped in front of the congressman's office. 
Republican Congressman Andy Harris drew a large crowd Wednesday to his annual town hall meeting in Bel Air, which he again said drew the best participation of any such event in his district. 
Harris, who represents Harford County, the Eastern Shore and parts of Baltimore and Carroll counties, blasted... 
Republican Congressman Andy Harris drew a large crowd Wednesday to his annual town hall meeting in Bel Air, which he again said drew the best participation of any such event in his district. 
Harris, who represents Harford County, the Eastern Shore and parts of Baltimore and Carroll counties, blasted... (BRYNA ZUMER) 
The local Together We Will group has already scheduled a town hall for Feb. 21 at Harford Community College, and subsequent meetings are scheduled for Carroll County and the Eastern Shore. 
"We welcome his attendance and participation," Lewis said of Harris. 
She noted about 500,000 Marylanders receive coverage through the ACA, and more than 50,000 of them live in Harris' district. 
"This is an issue that he should care about and be listening to us about," Lewis said. "Where are you Andy, that's what we want to know." DAVID ANDERSON 
The two phases of President Donald Trump's inauguration couldn't have been scripted in Hollywood or, for you "House of Cards" fans, in Joppa. Or could they? 
Jim Reilly, Harford County's Clerk of the Circuit Court, had a prime spot to watch the president's inauguration ceremony Friday, a seat in... 
The two phases of President Donald Trump's inauguration couldn't have been scripted in Hollywood or, for you "House of Cards" fans, in Joppa. Or could they? 
Jim Reilly, Harford County's Clerk of the Circuit Court, had a prime spot to watch the president's inauguration ceremony Friday, a seat in... (DAVID ANDERSON) 
Harris was not in his Bel Air office Monday, but his community liaison, Mary O'Keeffe, met with the handful of marchers who entered the office. 
O'Keeffe met with the marchers in pairs behind closed doors. 
Bob McSherry, of Bel Air, said later that O'Keeffe had been "very friendly, very welcoming." 
McSherry said his concerns include the ACA, air pollution and its harmful effects on human health and the House and Senate's recent repeal of an Obama Administration rule prohibiting dumping of coal waste in streams. 
McSherry noted that in Maryland counties that Trump won – such as Harford – "a lot of people have signed up for the ACA." 
Harris' First Congressional District covers the Eastern Shore, Harford County north of I-95 and parts of northern Baltimore and Carroll counties. 
The congressman is popular among the district's Harford County voters, who have given him wide margins in his four successful elections for Congress, as well as in 2008 when he first ran but lost. 
At the several town hall meetings Harris has held at least annually in Bel Air since being elected, Obamacare has come up for discussion and criticism among those present. 
Bryan Shuy, an aide to Harris, could not immediately be reached via phone or email for comment on the protest.
